title: Analyzing Some of the Implications of Government’s Move on Corporate Tax Rate Cut
text:
Yesterday, from 30% to 22% and 15% for new manufacturing companies. The markets rewarded this initiative from the government as surged by more than 5% in yesterday's trading. However, there are no free lunches in this world. Although this move will help revive the ailing Indian economy, there are some negative implications that we need to understand as well.

First of all, this decision from the government will cost it Rs. 1.45 lakh crore per year. This could result in a fiscal deficit growing from the current 3.3% of GDP to 4.0% of GDP. Widening of fiscal deficit could stoke inflationary pressures. We need to remember that the government has already budgeted to spend Rs. 70,000 crores on public sector banks recapitalization, which has already stretched the finances. Plus India’s GST collections have dropped to Rs 98,202 crore in August from over Rs 1.02 lakh crore in July, hurting revenue collections even further.

This news was negative for the bond market, as the 10-year bond yields surged by 15 bps yesterday. There is a feeling that the government will now need to borrow more to meet its expenses, which pushed up the bond yields. However, with RBI continuing with its rate-cutting spree, the bond yields could again come down.

There is a hope that the government will recover the loss from corporate tax reduction through other means, which includes taking divestment options. A few days back, of Bharat Petroleum Corp. Ltd. These incidents will help the government raise revenues to counter the shortfall.
